markdown: There will be [server maintenance works](https://blog.openstreetmap.org/2016/05/02/planned-server-outage-9th-may/) on 9th and 10th of May. OSM API will be read only during this time, therefore you cannot edit OSM. More information and updates can be found at the [OSM Wiki](https://wiki.openstreetmap.org/wiki/2016_May_server_maintenance).

Starting with version 0.5.5, [CGImap](https://github.com/zerebubuth/openstreetmap-cgimap), the C++ implementation of OSM API, [calculates](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/dev/2016-October/029544.html) the usage limits based on the sent OAuth tokens instead of IP address of the editor who sends the token. CGImap also supports the `/changesets/#{id}` API call now.

Frederik Ramm is in a [look out](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/dev/2016-November/029557.html) for developers/admins, who would be interested in building and maintaining an OSM Sandbox around the test OSM APIs.

Matt Amos [announced](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/announce/2017-February/000103.html) on the   Announce mailing list   that the OSM API and the osm.org website will be temporarily unavailable on Sunday, March 12 due to a software upgrade, which will start at 11:00 UTC and hopefully take no longer than one hour.
Wille Marcel, author of OSMCha, [suggests](https://github.com/openstreetmap/openstreetmap-website/issues/1618) on GitHub to add an API for user blocks to the OSM API.

The OSMF [reports](https://blog.openstreetmap.org/2017/12/08/openstreetmap-receives-25000-grant-from-american-red-cross/) in the official OpenStreetMap blog that OSM received a $25,000 donation from the American Red Cross to purchase a fallback server for the OSM API's main database server. This [server](https://wiki.osmfoundation.org/wiki/Board/Minutes/2017-03-21#2017.2F1:_Give_green_light_to_server_purch) is already up and running.

Frederik Ramm [suggests](https://github.com/openstreetmap/openstreetmap-website/issues/1720) the introduction of a feature in the OSM API to allow moderators to rename user accounts, which he wants to use against obscene usernames.

The OSM API [is currenly running slower](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2018-July/081009.html) than usual because the master OSM server is moving from Imperial College, London to the [Equinix data centre in Amsterdam](https://www.openstreetmap.org/way/460515888). In the transition period, a slower server  in York, England is serving as the database master server (we [reported](http://www.weeklyosm.eu/archives/10036#wn396_17018) earlier). The OWG [is looking](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2018-July/081020.html) for volunteers from the Amsterdam OSM community to help during the move on 25 and 26 July.

mmd would like to [introduce](https://github.com/zerebubuth/openstreetmap-cgimap/pull/174) limits of 5000 tags per object and 32,000 members per relation for the OSM API. In the ensuing discussion, Simon Poole [expresses](https://github.com/zerebubuth/openstreetmap-cgimap/pull/174#issuecomment-466743835) his doubts about the introduction of "arbitrary" limits.

The OSM API does not yet have a reasonable concept of how to deal with diff uploads that have been sent to the API and no answer received e.g. due to network problems. Most clients try to upload the diff again and therefore often create new objects twice. User mmd has started a [discussion](https://github.com/openstreetmap/openstreetmap-website/issues/2201) on GitHub.

The cleanup of our wiki gained some popularity recently. Apparently even pages which were deleted 7 years ago as been outdated still find readers today. Ilya Zverev [criticised](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2019-April/082480.html) the deletion of a wikipage about the testing of the API 0.6. Unfortunately (but highly predictably) the following discussion about the wiki deletion policy derailed to a semantic dispute about the [recent progress of the OSM API](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2019-April/082490.html), the [use of the word "vandalism"](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2019-April/082491.html) and the existence or non-existence of [gatekeepers](https://lists.openstreetmap.org/pipermail/talk/2019-April/082489.html) in OSM.

Changeset uploads are now handled by cgimap (written in C++) instead of the Rails Port (Ruby on Rails implementation of the OSM API), making uploads faster from editors like JOSM and iD. Ilya Zverev [explains](http://shtosm.ru/all/na-si-bystree/) ([translation](https://translate.google.com/translate?sl=ru&tl=en&u=http://shtosm.ru/all/na-si-bystree/)) the details in his blog "SHTOSM".

Frederik Ramm proposes introducing upload limits in the OSM API. There are two GitHub tickets: one in the [Rails port](https://github.com/openstreetmap/openstreetmap-website/issues/2342)  repository (now closed), and one in the [Cgimap](https://github.com/zerebubuth/openstreetmap-cgimap/issues/207) repository.

OsmApiClient is a C# package to handle the communication between your .Net project and the OSM API. See the [GitHub project](https://github.com/blackboxlogic/OsmApiClient), or [nuget package](https://www.nuget.org/packages/osmapiclient).

mmd [has announced](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/mmd/diary/392192) the new CGImap version 0.8.0 in his OSM user diary. Thanks to the new changeset endpoints, the OSM API 0.6 is now covered to the extent that running most parts of an OSM editing session is now possible using only CGImap.

The OSM API no longer supports TLS 1.0 and 1.1. Users of old Android devices (up to Android 4.4) should have a look at Simon Poole's [user blog](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/SimonPoole/diary/393865) to find out how to continue mapping with Vespucci on these devices.

Tobias Zwick compared the download times for StreetComplete before and after he reworked the download to exclusively use the OSM API, instead of individual Overpass queries, in [this chart](https://user-images.githubusercontent.com/4661658/97779862-4064a180-1b81-11eb-8536-a87daaa410bb.png). User mmd commented, on OSM Slack, that a similar reduction in download times might have been achieved through the [performance improvements he developed for Overpass](https://github.com/westnordost/StreetComplete/issues/1514#issuecomment-531902685) a year ago but which still haven't been merged. The StreetComplete changes have been released in [v26.0-beta1](https://github.com/westnordost/StreetComplete/releases/tag/v26.0-beta1).

The Engineering Working Group of OSMF [is looking for](https://blog.openstreetmap.org/2021/09/13/join-the-osmf-engineering-working-group/) people with knowledge of the technologies used in OSM's key systems: Rails port, Ruby on Rails in general, and the cgimap implementation of the OSM API. Knowledge of user interface design would be also welcome.

A change to API 0.6 will be [deployed](https://github.com/openstreetmap/openstreetmap-website/issues/1711) in the near future. After the change the OSM API will reject relations exceeding a certain number of relation members (significantly more than used in [any current relation](https://github.com/openstreetmap/openstreetmap-website/issues/1711#issuecomment-1014253589)).  The reason for the change is that _extremely_ large relations can cause [problems](https://github.com/zerebubuth/openstreetmap-cgimap/pull/174#issuecomment-1013266746) to downstream data consumers.  The largest current relation is [Tongass National Forest](https://www.openstreetmap.org/api/0.6/relation/6535292), which is already too large to be visible on the OSM website's 'relation view'.

kwiatek_123 has [written](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/kwiatek_123/diary/401120) osm_easy_api, which is a Python [package](https://github.com/docentYT/osm_easy_api/) for parsing OSM diffs and communicating with the OSM API.

For those of you who develop software that interacts with the OSM API, Paul Norman [reported](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/pnorman/diary/401157) that the Operations Working Group is considering deprecating HTTP Basic Auth and OAuth 1.0a in favour of OAuth 2.0 on the main API, in order to improve security and reduce code maintenance.

... that MapComplete now comes with layer [artwork](https://mapcomplete.org/artwork?z=14.9&lat=38.795462121715275&lon=-9.1831874612717)? The data is [retrieved](https://en.osm.town/@pietervdvn/111286566393753754) in real-time using Overpass or OSM API queries, and you can also add new data to OSM directly through MapComplete.

April Fools:

- On 1 April Osm2pgsql [went](https://osm2pgsql.org/news/2024/04/01/osm2pgsql-goes-ai.html) AI with a new cool   AI generated logo  . Amanda McCann [reacted](https://en.osm.town/@amapanda/112196570379280387) by saying  'we shouldn't let #AI anywhere near the code section'.
- StreetComplete [showed](https://en.osm.town/@F4FIA@mstdn.io/112195201921834197)  a 🌈 rainbow #EasterEgg to replace the direction logo. Ludovic [realised](https://en.osm.town/@usul@piaille.fr/112195092848534349) a   rainbow nyan cat   follows his edits and gislars felt [followed](https://en.osm.town/@gislars/112196405513409046) by a rainbow trace. 
- TrickFoxy  [proposed](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/TrickyFoxy/diary/403799) ⚡⚡⚡   OSM API v1.0⁴  . This proposal was stamped and approved by Kamil Monicz. This ignited some serious [discussion](https://www.openstreetmap.org/user/TrickyFoxy/diary/403799#comment56996) regarding future improvements for OSM API.

The new osmapiR package is now [published](https://cran.r-project.org/package=osmapiR) at CRAN, the official repository for R packages. After almost one year of development and polishing, the package implements all API calls and includes a complete documentation with examples for all functions. With this publication and existing packages [osmdata](https://cran.r-project.org/package=osmdata) (implementing overpass calls) and [osmextract](https://cran.r-project.org/package=osmextract) (work with .pbf files), R is now a first class language to work with OpenStreetMap.

The osmapiR v0.2.2 update [improved](https://docs.ropensci.org/osmapiR/news/index.html#osmapir-022) compatibility with the httr2 library, enhanced documentation for OpenStreetMap server changes, introduced new query parameters for changesets, and resolved bugs related to time-based queries, further streamlining OpenStreetMap data management in R.

_Qiita_ user krnsk17 [shared](https://qiita.com/krnsk17/items/673d4ba574b0fd2da833) :JA-s:>>>[:EN-t:](https://qiita-com.translate.goog/krnsk17/items/673d4ba574b0fd2da833?_x_tr_sl=auto&_x_tr_tl=EN) a comparison of APIs between OpenStreetMap and ZENRIN Maps. He created a search programme snippet to find a covered walkway for rainy days. He concluded that the proprietary ZENRIN API is easier to use, while the OSM API is more flexible but more challenging for implementing search functionality.
